MR. L. W. DONOUGH (Retirement) (Tributes)


    Mr Speaker: I have to inform hon. Members that, on the advice of the Medical Officer in charge of Officials, the Clerk of the Assembly, Mr Donough, asked to be allowed to proceed on retirement leave on the 1st of April last, and that his request has, with great regret, been granted by His Excellency the Governor.

    I need not say that His Excellency's regret is shared by me and, I am sure, by hon. Members.

    Mr Donough joined the Government in the General Clerical Service on the 10th of April, 1922.

    On the 1st of February, 1941, he was appointed an officer of the Straits Settlements Civil Service and on the 21st of October, 1949, an officer of the Colonial Administrative Service.

    After about 19 years in the General Clerical Service and before he became attached to the Legislature, Mr Donough served as:

    Chief Administrative Officer, Department of Supply, Malaya.

    Private Secretary to Secretary for Economic Affairs, Singapore.

    Deputy Superintendent of Census, Malaya (Headquarter), Ipoh.

    On the 1st of March, 1948, he became the Clerk of then Advisory Council and on the 1st of April, 1948, the Clerk of Councils, Singapore.

Column: 1739



    The latter post was abolished and a new appointment of Clerk of the Legislative Council was created with effect from the 1st of December, 1951. Mr Donough filled that post and became the first Clerk of this Legislative Assembly during the early part last year.

    Mr Donough, on his retirement, has thus served this country for a period of some 34 years.

    My association with Mr Donough has been of a very short duration - just over a year - but during that short period I have become aware of, his sterling quality as a loyal, capable and completely efficient officer, who has never hesitated to give of his utmost under any circumstances.

    His grasp of the intricacies of Parliamentary practice and procedure is second to none, and his retirement is indeed a great loss to this Assembly and to this country.

    I trust that now that he has been relieved of the anxieties and stresses of his post, Mr Donough will soon recover his health, and that he and Mrs. Donough will enjoy a happy and contented retirement.

    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to associate the Government Benches with the expressions of regret and appreciation which you have just made - regret, Sir, that the heavy pressure of duties during the past year has taken so grievous a toll on so conscientious an officer. We who have known him, we - and this refers to everyone of us - who have benefited by his assistance, his guidance and his courtesy, feel a greater regret at the loss of a very able and a very efficient officer.

    I would like to hope, Sir, that not only will he be fully recovered during the next few months of his leave, but that Singapore may yet benefit from his services in other departments.

    Sir, on behalf of all the Members on the Government Benches, I would like to express to Mr Donough our sincere good wishes on his retirement.

Column: 1740



    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, on this occasion the Opposition Benches would also like to express regret over the retirement of a very able officer. Indeed, Sir, Mr Donough has proved to everyone here that he is capable and that he will render aid to all Assemblymen, irrespective of whether they are on the Government Benches or on the Opposition Benches.

    He has shown that he is able to take on work which should indeed have been done by more people, and we have seen that his Office has been run very efficiently.

    Furthermore, his deep understanding of Parliamentary procedure has been of great help to all.

    We would like to express also our wishes for his happy retirement and quick recovery.

    The Chief Secretary (Mr W. A. C. Goode): Sir, I also would like, if I may, to pay tribute; and, speaking perhaps for once as a civil servant rather than as a Member of this House, I should like to say, Sir, that to me Mr Donough was an outstanding example of the finest type of civil servant. He was conscientious, a master of his subject, efficient, and completely loyal to the principles of his service and quite unsparing of himself in his thoroughness and in his sense of duty. It was by these qualities that, as you have said, Sir, he won his promotion from the Clerical Service to the Administrative Service and, finally, to the very responsible post of Clerk of this Assembly.

    During the past three years, Sir, particularly in the two years preceding the constitution of this Assembly, I saw a great deal of Mr Donough and of his work, and I cannot speak too highly of it. He was never satisfied, Sir, unless everything was done properly and efficiently, and, as you have said, he had a detailed knowledge of Parliamentary procedure which was of great benefit to everyone of us in this House and in the previous Legislative Council; and he had, what is more, Sir, an intense loyalty to the principles and traditions; of Parliamentary government. He was, quite rightly, most jealous of the rights

Column: 1741

of Members of the Legislature and of the independence of the Legislature from the Executive, and he defended both of those principles quite fearlessly. He was always respectful and yet dignified, but he was insistent on anything he held to be right; and both this Assembly, Sir, and the previous Legislative Councils owe him a great debt of gratitude for his knowledge and his wisdom, and we shall sorely miss his guidance in the future.

    I fully share the regrets that have been expressed that his keen sense of responsibility and his refusal to spare himself in the service of this Assembly have overtaxed his health so that he now has to give up this work to which he was so devoted and in which he so excelled. I know I can speak, Sir, on behalf of my officials, both in this House and throughout the public service, in associating ourselves with the tributes that have been paid to one of our colleagues. It is with real regret that we lose one who was an example to us and a friend, and we join, Sir, most sincerely in wishing Mr Donough good health and happiness in his retirement, and I hope that he will see the fruits of his labours in the future conduct of this Assembly.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

(Appointment)

LONDON CONFERENCE


    2. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Minister whether he will make a full statement on what the Government

Column: 1742

delegation intends to ask for at the London Conference.

    The Chief Minister: Yes, Sir, as full as I can in the present circumstances, and that will occur during the debate on the motion in my name.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, does that mean that the Chief Minister will make a statement in this debate on such matters as the future of the public service, internal security and citizenship?

INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
(Government economic policy)


    3. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether an Industrial Development Corporation is now in process of being set up; and whether he will make a statement detailing the economic policy of the Government.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, discussions with the Government of the Federation of Malaya and various financial institutions for a large scale Industrial Finance Corporation are still proceeding. The Singapore Government is considering, however, taking direct action through an organisation under my Ministry to stimulate and assist industrial development not requiring

Column: 1743

major capital assistance, and I hope that concrete proposals will be placed before this Assembly at an early date.

    The Government's economic policy was announced to this House in His Excellency's Address at the inaugural meeting on 22nd April of last year. This policy has been consistently pursued. I would also refer the Member for Changi (Mr Lim Cher Kheng) to the detailed reply given by my friend and colleague the Chief Minister (then concurrently the Minister for Commerce and Industry) to the Member for Tanglin (Mr Ede) on trade and industry contained in the Official Report of the Assembly, Vol. 1, No. 6 of 29th June, 1955.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, it seems to me that that policy has brought nothing tangible to Singapore, and we would like to know, too, whether he will give an indication that the policy has indeed been stepped up to get more industries going.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, my answer is that the Government is encouraging the industrialisation of Singapore as much as possible, and beyond that, if the hon. Member wishes to have details of what we are doing, I would like to invite him to come over and see me and I will give him that information, because it is too lengthy to be given in an oral reply like this.

INCIDENTS AT KALLANG MASS RALLY
(Statement)


    4. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary whether he will make a statement on the result of the investigations into the causes of the incidents which took place at the Kallang Mass Rally.

    Mr Goode: Yes, Sir,Investigations into the causes of the disorder at the Kallang Mass Rally have not yet been completed, but so far there is no evidence of any premeditated plan for interference with the rally or to create disorder.

    The causes of the incidents appear to be four. First, the collapse of the platform and the consequent disorganisation of the arrangements. Second,

Column: 1744

the angry frustration of a section of the crowd who were thus denied the speeches they had come to hear. Thirdly, a heavy shower of rain which caused part of the crowd to break into the terminal building; and, fourthly, the potential hostility to the police of a certain section of the crowd. The police had been apprehensive before the rally that any incident might set off serious disorders. The collapse of the platform before the speeches started disorganised the arrangements and disrupted the loudspeaker system, and the rally then divided into two groups - one group round the platform and one group in front of the terminal building. Around the platform there was a state of disorder. There were shouts to beat up the police on duty and some of the crowd began to pick up missiles to throw at the police. Political leaders there tried to quieten the crowd and songs, such as "Unity is strength", were sung. After about half an hour the crowd round the platform moved over to the terminal building to hear the speeches, but owing to the breakdown of the loudspeakers, they could not do so. At four minutes past six the Parliamentary delegation and most of the political leaders left. A large section of the crowd did not realise that the meeting was over and continued to shout and make a lot of noise. About this time it began to rain and most of the crowd started to move off; but about 3,000 remained, singing and shouting. There was also some dancing. A section of this crowd sought shelter from the rain in the terminal building, breaking through the doors. As they were disorderly and were doing damage, the police ejected them from the building and a police cordon was posted outside the building. The; singing and dancing continued and it became clear that this crowd of about 3,000 was excited and dissatisfied and demanding to hear their leaders speak.

    The police on duty were jeered and taunted by youths in the crowd and three spaces were cleared for dancing. At about 6.40 p.m. the chanting became

Column: 1745

more excited and a number of youths were seen working up their companions, lobbing pieces of wood, poles and banners at the police who remained steady at their posts. Suddenly a section of this crowd picked up stones from a heap of rubble and threw them at the police and at the building. The stone-throwers were mainly youths and the stoning was started by a small group whose numbers quickly increased to about 300 or more. The police then moved forward with batons, using their raincoats as shields against the stones, and for about 15 minutes the crowd alternately fell back before the police and advanced again throwing stones, until finally they were dispersed.

    Another group of several hundred attacked the police field post and the St. John Ambulance post with bottles and stones. They also were dispersed by the police and the whole area was finally cleared at five minutes past seven.

    20 police officers suffered minor injuries and 15 members of the public were treated for injuries, all of them minor except one, who was admitted to the hospital with cut in the head. One police van, some police radio equipment and a St. John ambulance were damaged and most of the windows in the terminal building were smashed. Eight persons have been arrested and charged with rioting.

    The police had been apprehensive of disorder because of slighting references made to the police at several P.A.P. meetings and because of the campaign in the Press by a large group of so-called Chinese cultural associations and students during the previous two weeks protesting against police refusals to issue licences for the performance of songs and dances of Communist meaning. These organisations held a further protest meeting at the Badminton Hall immediately prior to the mass rally. After it, at about 4 p.m., some 4,000 to 5,000 youths from that meeting marched in an orderly and disciplined manner to the rally. They carried a large banner depicting the Communist dove of peace. When they encountered police officers on duty, there was organised shouting of

Column: 1746

Merdeka. Their attitude was one of contempt for the police and very markedly different from the friendly and cheerful mood of the vast majority of the crowd.

    I cannot emphasise too strongly, Sir, the danger to law and order in Singapore of deliberately fostering ill-will and ridicule of the police who have to maintain and restore order. Should the authority of the police be undermined, then any incident can lead to serious riots. On this occasion we were fortunate that the vast majority of the crowd were good tempered and orderly and behaved like decent citizens, and the disorderly few never got out of hand.

    I should like to commend the restraint and discipline of the police on duty at Kallang and the services rendered by the St. John Ambulance men on duty amidst the disorders; and I wish to acknowledge fully, Sir the efforts made by several political leaders, including Members of this House, to calm down the crowd and get them to disperse.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Chief Secretary aware, from his police information, that at several P.A.P. rallies, far from making slighting references to the police we had, in fact, on one particular occasion especially, indicated that with Merdeka they ought to get more wages?

    Mr Goode: Sir, my information was slightly different. 'My' information was that at several P.A.P. meetings a number of speakers made derisive remarks about the police, including the Member for Tanjong Pagar, who raised a hoot of laughter from the crowd by his reference to putting up the pay of the police "when we get into power".

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Chief Secretary saying that anything was said at any of these rallies which was unlawful?

    Mr Goode: I am not prejudicing, Sir, the lawfulness or unlawfulness of what was said. What I am saying is that the speeches were derisory of the police.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Chief Secretary saying that any

Column: 1747

peech made by any political leader which does not praise the police is derisive?

    Mr Speaker: It is a matter of opinion.

    Mr Goode: Certainly not.

POLICE FORCE
(Malayanisation)


    5. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Secretary whether the Government has accepted the recommendations of the Malayanisation Commission to Malayanise the police force in three years.

    Mr Goode: The recommendations of the Commission are still under consideration by the Government.

    Mr John Ede: Is the Chief Secretary aware, Sir, that the next few years of transition are vital ones to Singapore, and is it not essential that men of the highest experience be retained in the police force during this period?

    Mr Goode: I have no hesitation, Sir, in giving an assurance that the Members of the Government will fully bear in mind their responsibility for the efficient administration of this territory.

Column: 1747

CITY COUNCIL ELECTIONS


    6. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Chief Secretary when it is proposed to hold the City Council elections.

    Mr Goode: Sir, the Government accepts the basic principles of the Report of the Committee on Local Government and a White Paper will be tabled before the June meeting of the Assembly.

    I hope that it will be possible to hold elections to the new Councils in December, but this depends on the mechanics of preparing electoral rolls.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, is the Chief Secretary not aware that two months ago the Chief Minister stated that Assistant Ministers would only have to serve three or four more months on the City Council, and will he implement this promise?

    Mr Goode: I suggest, Sir, that this be addressed to the Chief Minister.

ELECTORAL REGISTER


    7. Mr William Tan asked the Chief Secretary what steps have been taken by the Government to bring the electoral register up to date.

    Mr Goode: Sir, the following steps have been taken to bring the electoral register up to date.

    (1) Approximately 57,000 new voters are being brought on to the roll.

    (2) Enquiry is being made of all new voters who were recorded as having British nationality but who were born outside the United Kingdom and Colonies, the Federation of Malaya, North Borneo and Sarawak, to ascertain their citizenship status.

    (3) 65,000 changes of addresses have been recorded.

    (4) A regular check is being made of deaths notified to the Registrar of Births and Deaths and all deaths registered. Deletions are also being made from the electoral roll of persons who surrender their identity cards on departure from Malaya. Approximately 13,000 deletions from the roll have now been made as regards death and departure.

    (5) The names of persons obtaining registration as citizens of the United Kingdom and Colonies and naturalised as British subjects are being included in the roll. About 500 persons are affected.

    (6) The names are also being included on the register of locally domiciled persons serving in the armed services and with the police who are qualified as electors but do not hold identity cards. About 1,000 persons are so involved.

    (7) The electoral register has been checked for duplication and incorrect identity card numbers and enquiry is being made in each individual case where possible. There are about 450 persons in this category.

    Mr William Tan: Can the Hon. the Chief Secretary enlighten this House as to when this electoral register will be ready?

Column: 1749



    Mr Goode: Yes, Sir. The present programme is to publish the revisions as required by law in September, and then the new roll will be ready, I think, six weeks after that.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, does that mean that if a general election were necessary in the next month or two, there would be no electoral roll available?

    Mr Goode: Certainly not, Sir. The electoral roll continues in existence. All I am concerned with at the moment is revising it.

CENTRAL BANK
(Establishment)


    8. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Financial Secretary what is the position regarding the establishment of a Central Bank.

    Mr T. M. Hart: Sir, the issues involved in the establishment of Central Banking mechanism in Malaya are at present being investigated by Mr Watson of the Bank of England and Sir Sydney Caine, and their report is expected shortly.

GOVERNMENT PRIMARY SCHOOLS
(Admission and non-admission figures)


    9. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education (i) how many new students were admitted to Government primary schools at the beginning of the present school year; (ii) how many students of the age of 7 years who applied were admitted and how many were refused admission; and (iii) how many students of the age of 6 years were admitted.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: To the first part of the question, Sir, the number admitted at the beginning of the year was 15,553.

    To the second part of the question, all the seven-year old children of parents residing in Singapore, for whom application for admission to Government primary schools was made to the Ministry of Education, have been found places. Without further reference to schools, it is not possible to state how

Column: 1750

many seven-year old children from outside Singapore were admitted and how many refused. This information will be supplied as soon as it is available.

    To the third part of the question, Sir, it will be necessary to call for returns from schools as to the number of six-year old children who were admitted. This information will also be supplied as soon as it is available.

Column: 1750

SCHOOL BUILDING


    10. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education whether the Government has plans for building more schools on a cheaper basis than that of the Jervois Road Primary School, in respect of the construction of which a tender for $236,700 was recently accepted.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: The Government has been investigating and is now drawing up plans for primary school buildings that will be cheaper than those recently built. This new type of primary school will, by accommodating an extra stream, economise on the ground area required and also effect a considerable reduction in cost per classroom and in overhead expenses on staffing. For rural areas, small schools, each costing about half the normal type, are at present proposed.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that the Government has now been in office for a whole year and nothing has yet been done? Can he give an assurance that these new schools will be built as soon as possible?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: All new plans need time to work out by the architects in the Public Works Department, together with advice from the Education Ministry. We have not done exactly nothing. We have done a lot, such as finding sites for school buildings.

Column: 1750

CHINESE SCHOOL TEACHERS
(Salary payments)


    11. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of the delay, in some cases of three months, in the payment of salaries to the teachers of the Grant-in-Aid and fully aided Chinese schools; whether he

Column: 1751

is aware that this delay in payment of salaries to these teachers has not only caused hardship, but also created resentment; and what action he proposes to take in this matter.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: I am aware that there has been delay in payment of grant-in-aid in respect of salaries of teachers in Chinese aided schools since the beginning of this year, and I am fully aware of the hardships that late payment of salaries to teachers can cause. It would be an exaggeration, however, to say that the delay extends to three months. Changes in school staffs operative from January make the preparation and checking of the new year salary bills a very complicated task. In order to assist schools over the difficult period, all schools have received advances amounting to an average month's salary bill. The great majority have also received money for payment of January salaries. An additional clerk has been appointed to assist in this work, and I can assure the House that there will be no further delay in the future.

Column: 1751

GENERAL HOSPITAL
(Operation of Mistri Wing)


    12. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Health whether the Mistri Wing at the General Hospital is now in full operation.

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Mistri Wing can accommodate 300 beds, but at present only 150 beds are in use on all floors distributed according to the ages of the children. By the end of this year, it is expected that this hospital can be in full operation as more doctors and nurses will be available. It is further hoped to have a further 90 beds by July of this year when we expect a new batch of nurses to qualify at the end of June.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister suggest that although 300 beds are available and 150 are now in operation, there are not enough patients in Singapore to fill the other 150 beds?

Column: 1752



    Mr Braga: No child needing hospitalisation is refused. I am not aware of the number of patients in Singapore.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Is the Minister aware, Sir, of the constant harassing requests from quite a number of children at the Social Welfare Department for admission into hospitals?

    Mr Braga: If the last speaker had any information of that nature, he should have passed it on to me. I am not aware of any at the moment.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a matter of co-ordination between the Ministries.

    Mr John Ede: Will the Minister state why an expensive million-dollar building was constructed without at the same time ensuring that it could be adequately staffed from the beginning?

    Mr Braga: It must be realised, Mr Speaker, Sir, that it is uneconomical to build in stages and total postponement of construction would have denied even the 150 beds available to the sick children today.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Does it not indicate, Sir, that there is no forward planning so as to dovetail construction with staffing?

    Mr Speaker: It is a matter of opinion.

Column: 1752

DOCTORS
(SHORTAGE)


    13. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Health whether he can confirm that there is now no shortage of doctors in Singapore.

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, to answer the general question as to whether there is a shortage of doctors in Singapore is a difficult one, but I would say that there is a shortage of doctors in Singapore. The Medical Advisory Council advises me that there are 484 doctors on the medical register, but, measured by international standards, with a population of 1,200,000 in Singapore, we ought to have 1,300 doctors if a full medical cover is to be provided for every citizen.

Column: 1753



    Mr Lim Choon Mong: If there is a shortage of doctors, Sir, what steps is the Minister taking to remedy that?

    Mr Braga: I am not sure whether the last speaker is not confused. Is he asking me whether there is a shortage of doctors in Singapore or a shortage of doctors in my Ministry?
